N/AParks Canada AgencyThings to do - Sable Island National Park Reserveen2020-04-03https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/ns/sable/activThings to doSable Island National Park Reserve is a place to be awed by the power of nature. It is an extremely isolated location, and access to it is determined by constraints of weather and geography. Visitor experience opportunities are similar to other remote national parks in Canada, where there are few visitor facilities and the wilderness of the site constitutes an important feature of the experience.Contains Covid AlertThings to do - Sable Island National Park Reserve

N/AParks Canada AgencyPlan your visit - Sirmilik National Parken2020-03-17https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/nu/sirmilik/visitPlan your visitSpread across 22,000 square kilometres (13,665 square miles) of Baffin Island’s northeastern coast, Sirmilik is divided into three sections - Bylot Island, Oliver Sound and Borden Peninsula. It is renowned for its rich array of wildlife, from lemmings and polar bears to whales and more than 70 bird species. It is one of the most accessible parks in Nunavut.Contains Covid AlertPlan your visit - Sirmilik National Park

HealthPublic Health Agency of CanadaCOVID-19 Technical Brief: Masking and face shields for full duration of shifts in acute healthcare settingsen2020-04-19https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/health-professionals/technical-brief-masking-face-shields-full-duration-shifts-acute-healthcare-settings.htmlAcknowledgments; BibliographyCOVID-19, coronavirus, corona, virus, guidance, masks, eye protection, gown, gloves, face protection, masking, face shield, personal protective equipment, PPE, healthcare, hospitals, healthcare workers, hand hygiene, community transmission, asymptomatic, pre-symptomatic, pauci-symptomatic, physical distancing, preventionMain Covid-19 contentGuidance, RecommendationsCOVID-19 Technical Brief: Masking and face shields for full duration of shifts in acute healthcare settings
Environment and natural resourcesEnvironment and Climate Change CanadaAmherst Point Migratory Bird Sanctuaryen2020-03-31https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/migratory-bird-sanctuaries/locations/amherst-point.htmlNotice; Importance of the sanctuary: migratory birds and other wildlife; History; Landscape; Map of the area; Planning your visit; Key facts about Amherst Point Migratory Bird Sanctuary; Related links; Contact informationAmherst Point Migratory Bird Sanctuary (MBS) lies five km southwest of Amherst at the head of the Bay of Fundy. It was established in 1947 with the agreement of the landowners. However, to afford permanent habitat protection, the land was later acquired by the Canadian Wildlife Service (1973–1974) and designated as a component of the Chignecto National Wildlife Area. The landscape is a mosaic of ponds, marshes, forests and old farm fields.Contains Covid AlertGeneral PublicAmherst Point Migratory Bird Sanctuary

HealthHealth CanadaChloroquine and hydroxychloroquine can have serious side effects. These drugs should be used only under the supervision of a physician. - Recalls and safety alertsen2020-04-25https://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72885a-eng.phpSummary; Issue; What you should do; What industry professionals should do; Media enquiries; Public enquiriesOttawa – Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine may cause serious side effects, including serious heart rhythm problems. The risk of these side effects may increase at higher doses, or if the drugs are used in combination with other drugs, such as the antibiotic azithromycin. Patients should use these drugs only under the supervision of a physician. Health Canada is concerned that some people may be directly buying and using chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine to prevent or treat COVID-19 without a prescription.Main Covid-19 contentGeneral PublicChloroquine and hydroxychloroquine can have serious side effects. These drugs should be used only under the supervision of a physician. - Recalls and safety alerts

N/AParks Canada AgencyVisitor safety - Sirmilik National Parken2020-01-08https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/nu/sirmilik/securite-safetyVisitor safetyOne of Nunavut’s most accessible parks, Sirmilik is near Pond Inlet, where all visitors must register, attend orientation and report for post-trip de-briefing. A friendly, mostly Inuit community, Pond Inlet has outfitters offering pre-arranged park shuttles by boat in summer and snowmobiles in winter for hiking, climbing, kayaking, skiing and mountaineering adventures.Contains Covid AlertVisitor safety - Sirmilik National Park

N/AParks Canada AgencyThings to do - Halifax Citadel National Historic Siteen2020-04-06https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/ns/halifax/activThings to doStaff at the Halifax Citadel have crafted many ways to transport you back in time to the life of a Victorian era soldier. Join a guided tour or explore the various sites within the fort on your own. Watch the noon firing of the gun, listen to the stirring sounds of the bagpipes, or join a signature experience and become part of the 78th Highlanders for the day. Educators can also join in an engaging Canadian history program.Contains Covid AlertThings to do - Halifax Citadel National Historic Site

Environment and natural resourcesEnvironment and Climate Change CanadaLast Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuaryen2020-03-27https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/migratory-bird-sanctuaries/locations/last-mountain-lake.htmlNotice; Importance of the sanctuary: migratory birds and other wildlife; History; Landscape; Map of the area; Planning your visit; Key facts about Last Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary; Related links; Contact informationLast Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary (MBS) is situated 165 km southeast of Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. The MBS includes 4736 hectares of the north end of a large natural lake (Last Mountain Lake) and some of the adjacent uplands. It is within the Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area (NWA) and located in the Moist Mixed-grass Prairie ecoregion of Saskatchewan.Contains Covid AlertGeneral PublicLast Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary

By doing your homework before you leave, you minimize the chances of something going wrong. Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 contentStories
N/ACanada Revenue AgencySelf-care tips for managers and their teams during COVID-19en2020-04-17https://www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/services/covid-19-employee-supplier/covid-19-employee-info/self-care-tips-managers-teams-covid19.htmlMain Covid-19 contentSelf-care tips for managers and their teams during COVID-19
N/AParks Canada AgencyThings to do - Fort Anne National Historic Siteen2020-04-02https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/ns/fortanne/activThings to doThe grassy Parade Square and impressive earthen ramparts of Fort Anne are mainly quiet today. But they have witnessed four centuries of tumultuous history. Inside the fort’s museum, housed inside a 1797 officers’ quarters, visitors can learn how Europe’s powers battled for the coveted site for literally hundreds of years. Outside, explore the fort’s defensive banks, moats and bastions and, after dark, take a guided, candlelit tour of the Garrison Graveyard.Contains Covid AlertThings to do - Fort Anne National Historic Site

Why not?!; “I will vote one day”: Strengthening children’s voices in South Africa; Global Affairs Canada worked with RENEW to design and implement the Accelerating Business Growth project in Ethiopia.; Sherbrooke University aims to turn cross-border research into business opportunities.; Mexican students bring big benefits to Thunder Bay and Orillia; Memorial University’s Marine Institute creates a virtuous cycle in Indonesia, and beyond; Rosedale Academy takes Canadian high-school education around the world; The world’s oil and gas industry beats a path to SAIT; Canadian filmmaker gains eye-opening work experience around the world; Embracing diversity through artistic exchange: From Toronto to Valparaíso, Chile; Canada’s Sam Bat turns maple into winning baseball bats for pros; Merry’s banana split; Women at the table: Peace and security in Côte d’Ivoire; Indigenous Voices from Peru, Bolivia, and Canada: Protecting Lake TiticacaThese stories tell us about some of Canada’s international efforts for development, trade and foreign policy. They introduce the projects and partners that drive change. We meet people from all over the world and learn how our actions can make lives better in families, their communities, and sometimes an entire nation.Main Covid-19 contentStories

Canada and the worldGlobal Affairs CanadaThe Canada Fund for Local Initiatives - Lesotho, Madagascar, Mauritius, Namibia, South Africaen2020-04-21https://www.international.gc.ca/world-monde/funding-financement/cfli-fcil/2020/south_africa-afrique_du_sud.aspx?lang=engProgram Description ; How to apply; General Information; Organizations eligible to apply for CFLI funding ; Thematic priorities ; COVID-19 Crisis ; Gender-based analysis  ; Eligible costsThe CFLI is a program designed to support small-scale, high-impact projects in developing countries that align with Global Affairs Canada’s thematic priority areas for engagement. The program is directed at projects conceived and designed predominantly by local partners. Projects are selected and approved by the relevant Canadian embassy or high commission. The CFLI also serves to support positive bilateral relations between Canada and recipient countries and their civil societies by deepening contacts and supporting local endeavours.Main Covid-19 contentThe Canada Fund for Local Initiatives - Lesotho, Madagascar, Mauritius, Namibia, South Africa

N/AParks Canada AgencyKejimkujik National Park and National Historic Siteen2020-03-27https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/ns/kejimkujikThere are many sides to Kejimkujik National Park and National Historic Site. Inland, old growth hemlock, sugar maple and yellow aspen trees border warm-water lakes with quartzite shores. Kejimkujik Seaside, a separate landscape, juxtaposes with colourful barrens, granite cobbles and white-sand beaches. The land also tells the tale of the Mi’kmaw, carved in stone and illuminated through story and legend. Paddle the waters, hike the trails and discover the rich diversity of Kejimkujik.Contains Covid AlertKejimkujik National Park and National Historic Site

N/AParks Canada AgencyVisitor safety - Quttinirpaaq National Parken2020-03-27https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/nu/quttinirpaaq/securite-safetyVisitor safetyOn Ellesmere Island, less than 800 kilometres (500 miles) from the North Pole, Quttinirpaaq is the world’s northernmost national park. If heading into the park, it is essential to be self-sufficient and experienced. Individual travellers are welcome, though most visitors arrive with an outfitter for one or two weeks of outdoor activities like hiking, skiing, mountain climbing or traversing ice caps and glaciers.Contains Covid AlertVisitor safety - Quttinirpaaq National Park

N/AParks Canada AgencyVisitor safety - Wrecks of HMS Erebus and HMS Terror National Historic Siteen2019-05-29https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/nu/epaveswrecks/securite-safetyVisitor safetySafety is everyone's responsibility. At Parks Canada, we do our part to make sure you can have a safe visit by assessing the risks, managing hazards, and making sure that safety information is freely available to everyone. You can do your part as visitors by making sure you seek out the information you need to stay safe and make well-informed decisions while enjoying these special places. Visit our websites and stop at a visitor centre to speak with our employees for the most up to date information. Make sure you are fully prepared for whatever activities you choose to participate in so you can have a safe, enjoyable, and memorable visit.Contains Covid AlertVisitor safety - Wrecks of HMS Erebus and HMS Terror National Historic Site

N/AParks Canada AgencyThings to do - Kejimkujik National Park and National Historic Siteen2020-04-03https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/ns/kejimkujik/activThings to doDiscover deep traditions in harmony with pristine nature in Kejimkujik National Park and National Historic Site. A Dark Sky Preserve displays the science and stories of the stars. Aboriginal rock-art illuminates thousands of years of Mi’kmaw heritage. Interconnecting waterways and woodland trails lead paddlers and hikers through an ecosystem rich with wildlife. And the Atlantic coast reveals its beauty in Kejimkujik Seaside.Contains Covid AlertThings to do - Kejimkujik National Park and National Historic Site

N/AParks Canada AgencyWrecks of HMS Erebus and HMS Terror National Historic Siteen2020-03-20https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/nu/epaveswrecksIn 1845, explorer Sir John Franklin set sail from England with two ships, HMS Erebus and HMS Terror, in search of a Northwest Passage across what is now Canada's Arctic. The ships and crews vanished, prompting a massive search that continues to this day. A breakthrough was made in September 2014 when an expedition led by Parks Canada discovered the wreck of HMS Erebus. This discovery lead to the creation of the Wrecks of HMS Erebus and HMS Terror National Historic Site of Canada.Contains Covid AlertWrecks of HMS Erebus and HMS Terror National Historic Site

Using the Access to Information and Privacy (ATIP) Online Request service is a fast, easy and convenient way to submit a request. This service allows individuals to make online requests for information to participating government institutions instead of having to print, scan, mail or email a paper form.Contains Covid AlertGeneral PublicMake an access to information or personal information request

N/AParks Canada AgencyQausuittuq National Parken2020-03-20https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/nu/qausuittuqQausuittuq National ParkImagine a cluster of islands in a frozen sea, a home for the endangered Peary caribou, a traditional hunting and fishing area that has sustained Inuit of Resolute Bay since the time of their relocation in the 1950’s; Qausuittuq National Park is all of that and more.Contains Covid AlertQausuittuq National Park
Environment and natural resourcesEnvironment and Climate Change CanadaVaseux Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuaryen2020-03-27https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/migratory-bird-sanctuaries/locations/vaseux-lake.htmlNotice; Importance of the sanctuary: migratory birds and other wildlife; Landscape; Map of the area; Planning your visit; Key facts about Vaseux Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary; Related links; Contact informationVaseux Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary (MBS) is situated 5 km south of Okanagan Falls on Highway 97 in the Okanagan Valley of southern British Columbia. Vaseux Lake is in the Osoyoos-Arid Biotic Area, which is a northern extension of the Great Basin Desert.The MBS was originally established to provide protection to Trumpeter Swans. Canada Geese use the site extensively and nest in numbers exceeding 200 on Hatfield Island.Contains Covid AlertGeneral PublicVaseux Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary

Environment and natural resourcesEnvironment and Climate Change CanadaGeorge C. Reifel Migratory Bird Sanctuaryen2020-03-27https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/migratory-bird-sanctuaries/locations/george-c-reifel.htmlNotice; Importance of the sanctuary: migratory birds and other wildlife; Landscape; Map of the area; Planning your visit; Key facts about George C. Reifel Migratory Bird Sanctuary; Related links; Contact informationGeorge C. Reifel Migratory Bird Sanctuary (MBS) is situated 5 km south of Vancouver, at the northern end of Westham Island in the Fraser River estuary. The sanctuary is named in honour of George C. Reifel, a nature enthusiast and conservationist who purchased land in the 1920s to create a private hunting retreat. Ownership was transferred to the Crown in the 1960s to create the MBS.Contains Covid AlertGeneral PublicGeorge C. Reifel Migratory Bird Sanctuary

Use this form to submit corrections or comments on this row in the inventory. Comments will be reviewed by DTO

Web Content Inventory Instructions

The COVID-19 Web content inventory tool relies on data from two sources:

  • Canada.ca search results
  • AEM web crawl

We aim to update the tool daily.

You can use the tool to validate and improve metadata. You can also identify:

  • what COVID-19 content exists for a particular theme or department
  • duplication or overlap
  • out-of-date materials

Tool use examples

These examples show specific uses for validation of content and updates to metadata.

E.g. The Benefits theme lead wants to ensure there are no out-dated alerts

  • On the left side of the page, select Benefits in the theme drop down
  • Select “alerts” for content type
  • Click “Filter” button to show results
  • Click and hold the URL column header and reposition it to the left of the page title
  • Select each page URL to verify that the alerts are still accurate

E.g. The Department of Finance wants to ensure their COVID-19 pages are following the metadata guidance for titles

  • On the left side of the page, select Department of Finance in the departments list
  • Click the filter button to show results
  • Click and hold the TITLE column and move it to the right of the Department column
  • A review of results shows COVID appears in some cases, but not all
  • Click the “Excel” button towards the top of the page to download a spreadsheet of these results
  • Use the spreadsheet to provide clear instructions to the department content manager

Considerations

  • The tool is available in English and French
  • The left side of the page provides the main site filters – theme, department and four types of content:
  • Main COVID-19 content returns pages that include substantive information on health, economics, restrictions, etc. Generally, pages accessible from Canada.ca/covid19 are “main COVID-19” content.
  • Alerts returns pages that include an visual and textual alert, with some content related to COVID-19, usually in relation to a service interruption.
  • Links returns pages that include a link to a page with COVID-19 content
  • News returns 5 types of news releases and announcements, including:
    • backgrounders
    • media advisories
    • news releases
    • speeches
    • statements
  • The columns can be rearranged by clicking, holding and dragging them to the position you want The toggles at the top of the page give you additional control over what you see Use the Filter reset button if your results are not what you expected

Generate an Excel report for internal use

To generate an Excel report:

  • Use the filter tool, to get the results you want,
  • click the Excel button.
  • Use the comments column in the Excel report to indicate changes or questions for your web team, program area or communications team

This may be useful for:

  • corrections
  • removal or archiving of pages
  • adding new pages to your cluster

Submit comments to the Digital Transformation Office (DTO)

To submit comments about a specific page to the DTO, click the Submit button in the Comments column for that page in the inventory tool. Comments are sent to: dto.btn@tbs-sct.gc.ca

Comments will help us to complete a QA on the tool. Right now we see this tool as an alpha release, there are improvements and corrections required.
